headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt for the week of April 16—April 21, 2012.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway's Annual Letters, 1977-2011
summary: See what Warren Buffett had to say about current company executives over the years.

headline: Tupac, Live in Concert
summary: The online buzz about the ghostly image of deceased rapper Tupac Shakur used on stage at last weekend's Coachella music festival.

headline: Reliable Travel Umbrellas
summary: These compact umbrellas are light and easily packed, but sturdy enough to stand up to rain showers.

headline: The Marriage Gap
summary: Much has been made of Mitt Romney's problems reaching women voters, but an even bigger gap separates him from President Obama than the "gender gap."

headline: Infoblox, Ixia: Biggest Price Gainers (BLOX, XXIA)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Organizations That Have Sought to Use Drones
summary: See a list of what groups have requested licenses from the FAA to use drones, and the status of that request.

headline: A Guide to the French Election
summary: A look at the leading candidates. Plus, the candidates key to the second round and opinion polls.

headline: Overheard: BP in Russia; SuperGroup
summary: Two years on from the Deepwater Horizon disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, BP is under pressure over its safety record on the other side of the world, in Russia.

headline: The H&S Party Count
summary: Spring: It's New York's season for love, outdoor concerts and fancy parties. The social calendar kicked into high gear this week; so how did one soiree stack up to another?

headline: Pound Gains on Dollar
summary: The U.K. currency rallied to touch a five-month high against the dollar on signs of improving U.K. consumer demand and expectations the country's policy makers will pause from further monetary stimulus.

headline: Knicks Go Back To Bad Habits
summary: Amar'e Stoudemire returned Friday night from a bulging disc in his back, and so did the dysfunctional New York Knicks: the ones where Stoudemire and Carmelo Anthony couldn't play together. The playoffs-bound Knicks lost to the Cleveland Cavaliers, 98-90.

headline: Mets Tie It in 9th, Only to Lose It in 10th to Giants
summary: On Wednesday, a rough outing by Mets closer Frank Francisco was a mere footnote in a blowout loss. This time, Francisco's woes proved far more costly.

headline: Three More Secret Service Agents Resign
summary: Three more Secret Service agents have resigned after allegations involving prostitutes at a Colombia hotel, the agency said late Friday, bringing the total of those leaving to six.

headline: Infoblox Jumps 41%, Midstates Up 2%
summary: Network control automation company Infoblox jumped in its trading debut, while oil exploration company Midstates Petroleum opened modestly higher after pricing well below its expected range.

headline: Proofpoint Surges 30% Post-IPO
summary: Security-software company Proofpoint saw its shares jump in their trading debut on Nasdaq after pricing above range.

headline: 'Highlanders' Spoil Boston's Party
summary: Fenway Park celebrated its centennial Friday, the teams wore old-time uniforms and the New York Yankees (masquerading as the New York Highlanders) spoiled the Boston celebration with a 6-2 win over the Red Sox.

headline: It Takes Craft to Keep Little Ones Clamoring for Mac and Cheese
summary: It may sound cheesy, but at Kraft, noodling around with novel shapes is key. Al dente can't compete with SpongeBob SquarePants.

headline: Pasta Patents
summary: See some of the patents held by Kraft Foods' pasta architect Guillermo Haro and others.

headline: Kentucky Lawmakers Approve Drug-Abuse Bill
summary: The Kentucky legislature approved a bill to crack down on prescription-drug abuse in a state with a growing problem of addiction to painkillers.

headline: Sixth Seed Would Give Knicks Some Hope
summary: The Knicks have already clinched a playoff spot for just the third time since 2001. But if they want to dramatically improve their chances of winning a playoff series for the first time since 2000, they must improve their playoff seeding in the season's final week.

headline: Mets Are a Team With No True Center
summary: Until last year, the New York Mets' center field situation didn't require much thought. But Carlos Beltran is now gone, leaving behind a gaping hole that hasn't been filled.

headline: Knicks Sign Gadzuric, Waive Bill Walker
summary: The New York Knicks added a big man for their playoff run on Friday, signing free-agent center Dan Gadzuric and waiving swingman Bill Walker.

headline: Sudden Death Is Certain Death
summary: It is a difficult thing to go through four consecutive playoff games without trailing for a single second during regulation, yet the Rangers have done exactly that in their first-round series against the Ottawa Senators.

headline: NHL Asks: College or Canada?
summary: Collegiate players are narrowing the gap on those from the Canadian juniors.

headline: U.N. Reaches Syria Cease-Fire Compromise
summary: The West and Russia presented clashing plans for when to deploy hundreds of U.N. ceasefire monitors to Syria, setting the stage for further diplomatic wrangling on a day that violence in the country claimed nearly 30 lives.

headline: Witnesses at the Scene
summary: Current photography exhibitions of Frank Gohlke, Alex Prager and Tim Hetherington.

headline: Elevating Women and Art
summary: The Brooklyn Museum's annual Artists Ball gathered locals and island-dwellers alike for a long and elegant toast to the Sackler Center for Feminist Art.

headline: Sea Cliff Prizes Status as 'a Bit Different'
summary: The village of Sea Cliff, on Long Island's north shore, has little in the way of mall-type shopping, new development and modern mansions. And that's exactly how residents of this one-square-mile community like it.

headline: Handyman Denies Patz Link
summary: A lawyer for a handyman who has come under renewed scrutiny in the 1979 disappearance of a 6-year-old Manhattan boy said Friday that the man denies any involvement in the case.

headline: Guard at Met In Gun Mishap
summary: A security guard at the Metropolitan Museum of Art accidentally shot himself in the leg Friday afternoon while cleaning his handgun in a basement locker room.

headline: Holland Tunnel Repairs
summary: New Jersey-bound motorists won't be able to use the Holland Tunnel during the overnight hours this weekend. The New Jersey-bound lanes will be closed from 1 a.m. to 8 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday for roadway retexturing.

headline: A Spot of Nice in Chelsea
summary: It's hard to miss La Promenade des Anglais. You'll spot the Chelsea restaurant's long, white awning from down the street.

headline: Comforting the Wealthy
summary: Ann Kadet on high-end shops in Manhattan and Brooklyn that sell items which can be found at any Wal-Mart or bodega at a smaller price.

headline: New Spin on Oddball Pitch
summary: "Knuckleball!," which makes its debut Saturday in the first of four screenings at the Tribeca Film Festival, follows Mets pitcher R.A. Dickey and former Boston Red Sox hurler Tim Wakefield through the 2011 season.

headline: Principal Is Facing Dismissal
summary: A principal at a popular Chinese dual-language primary school on the Lower East Side faces dismissal after the Department of Education found she violated a number of regulations.

headline: Asians Lead City in Growth Rate
summary: While Chinatown's Asian population declined over the past decade, the Asian footprint widened in far-flung neighborhoods from Sunset Park in Brooklyn to Murray Hill in Queens.

headline: Apple Keeps Rolling Downhill
summary: Apple's shares continued their rapid descent, extending a decline from an April 10 intraday peak to more than 10%.

headline: Dow Snaps 2-Week Losing Streak
summary: The Dow industrials rose after better-than-forecast quarterly reports from Microsoft and General Electric, while Apple's slide helped lead the Nasdaq into the red.

headline: A New House, and Trouble in Tarheel Country
summary: And other news from the campaign trail, in On the Stump.

headline: Occupy Looks to May Day
summary: After an autumn marked by spontaneous marches, arrests and raucous street theater, Occupy Wall Street is changing tactics as it plans a march next month that some organizers hope will rekindle the movement's momentum.

headline: SEC: Robot Stock Picker Is a Fraud
summary: A pair of British twin brothers fooled thousands of U.S. investors who believed a fictitious "stock-picking robot" could spot penny stocks set to soar in price, the SEC said in a civil suit.

headline: IMF Nearly Doubles Its War Chest for Crisis
summary: G-20 financial leaders committed to boosting IMF resources by more than $430 billion to deal with the euro zone's debt crisis.

headline: GE Net Falls 12%; Energy Unit Shines
summary: General Electric's earnings declined 12% but rose on an operating basis, fueled by renewed profit growth at its big energy-infrastructure division.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: William Tucker on oil speculators, Adam Smith and Barack Obama.

headline: Elizabeth Warren's Tax Epiphany
summary: The liberal heroine finds an ObamaCare levy to repeal.

headline: Test Question Flunks
summary: Eighth-graders were stumped by a Daniel Pinkwater tale rewritten as an exam question. The author was also bewildered. Finally, under criticism, officials invalidated the puzzler about a talking pineapple.

headline: Citi's $8 Billion Rejection
summary: The size of Citi's request for stock buybacks, which was bigger than some analysts had expected, might have hurt the bank''s chances of winning Fed approval.

headline: Laffer and Moore: A 50-State Tax Lesson for the President
summary: Over the past decade, states without an income levy have seen much higher growth than the national average. Which state will be next to abolish theirs?

headline: California Farmers Retool to Feed China
summary: For decades, California's agricultural Central Valley thrived on Americans' seemingly endless appetites. Now, farmers are going after a different group: middle-class Asians attracted to Western fare.

headline: Noonan: America's Crisis of Character
summary: The nation seems to be on the wrong track, and not just economically.

headline: Teen's Killer Says 'Sorry,' Gets Bail
summary: The judge in the Trayvon Martin case set bail at $150,000 for George Zimmerman. The 28-year-old neighborhood-watch volunteer took the stand at his bond hearing, apologizing to the Florida teen's parents.

headline: Scandals Undercut Obama's Message
summary: The scandals plaguing the Secret Service and General Services Administration have been disconcerting enough for the Obama administration. But beyond that, they have the potential to be a political liability for Democrats.

headline: Big Test Set for Tea Party Muscle
summary: Challenges to two veterans of the Republican establishment, Sens. Orrin Hatch and Richard Lugar, will signal whether tea-party activists and their allies still have the power to reshape the party.

headline: Jenkins: Chesapeake and Apple, the Mighty Fallen?
summary: McClendon's problem is leverage. Apple's is margins.

headline: All Heat, No Light, in Fire Data
summary: Fire departments across the country are having a hard enough time measuring the time they take to respond to emergency calls, let alone meeting national guidelines for how quickly they should arrive on the scene.

headline: Death Sentence Blocked Under Bias Law
summary: A judge in North Carolina issued a landmark ruling that overturned a death sentence after finding that race played a "significant factor" in the jury-selection process.

headline: Democratic PAC Seeks Help From Bill Clinton
summary: The main super PAC backing President Barack Obama's re-election has asked former President Bill Clinton to step in to court donors, according to a friend of the former president.

headline: Regulators Close Bank in New Jersey
summary: Regulators closed Fort Lee Federal Savings Bank in Fort Lee, N.J., bringing the nationwide tally of bank failures to 17 for the year.

headline: Michelle Van Cleave: Russian Spies Haven't Gone Away
summary: Even when presented with extensive evidence of espionage, this White House looks the other way.

headline: Hollande Ramps Up ECB Rhetoric
summary: French Socialist presidential candidate François Hollande pressed the ECB to cut interest rates and lend directly to euro-zone member countries to bolster economic activity, in the latest escalation of campaign rhetoric.

headline: South Sudan Pulls Back From Brink of War
summary: South Sudan, bowing to international pressure from even its staunchest allies, said it would withdraw its army from an oil town it occupied along a disputed border with Sudan.

headline: Joel Kotkin: The Great California Exodus
summary: A leading U.S. demographer and 'Truman Democrat' talks about what is driving the middle class out of the Golden State.

headline: US Airways CEO Talks Up Merger
summary: US Airways' chief executive said the company has a "unique opportunity" to pursue a merger with American Airlines and has the backing of unions representing more than 50,000 workers at the rival carrier.

headline: Google's Schmidt Gets Raise After Leaving CEO Post
summary: Google raised Eric Schmidt's annual salary to $1.25 million from $1 when he stepped aside as CEO and moved to the role of executive chairman.

headline: Justin Belmont: A Facebook Shopping List
summary: What might the company buy next? Choices range, of course, from Disinterest to Darfur-Square to Foesbook.

headline: The Student-Debt Playbook
summary: There are a number of ways to reduce, rework or even get rid of your federal loans. Here are some.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Andy Xie writes that limiting what other people can do seems to be central to the current European thinking on fairness.

headline: When Retirees Face Health-Plan Cuts
summary: Many employers have been shifting more costs to retirees even as they receive billions in government subsidies to offset their own costs.

headline: Spain Moves Against Argentina
summary: Spain's first economic response to Argentina's seizure of Repsol YPF SA's local unit will be a reprisal affecting its biodiesel exports that targets the soybean industry in the South American country.

headline: Volcano Puts Mexico on Alert
summary: The towering Popocatépetl volcano outside Mexico City rumbled loudly and spewed plumes of ash and hot rocks high into the sky.

headline: Romney's Budget Promise Proves Tough Test
summary: During his primary campaign, Mitt Romney vowed to balance the federal budget by 2020 and sharply shrink spending by 2016. His pledge to do so without cutting Social Security or Medicare benefits is causing some headaches for his economic-policy team.

headline: Besting Argentina in Court Doesn't Seem to Pay
summary: If Repsol YPF SA contests Argentina's nationalization of its local energy assets before the World Bank's arbitration center, the Spanish company will have to take a place in a long line of aggrieved corporate plaintiffs.

headline: Dewey in Discussions With Rival Law Firm
summary: New York law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf is in preliminary talks with rival firm Greenberg Traurig LLP about a possible transaction.

headline: Giuliani Wades Into Serbian Politics
summary: Former New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani was dragged into the swirling waters of Balkan politics after participating in public events with two opposition-party candidates in hotly contested election fights in Serbia.

headline: Week in Words
summary: Here's Erin McKean's field guide to unusual words in this week's Wall Street Journal: boondocking, particularist, hotelling and bar codes.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of April 21-22, 2012

headline: Transit of Venus: Celestial Event Sparked Revolution
summary: June's transit of Venus recalls science's first international collaboration—despite war, storms, typhus and frozen brandy.

headline: In Your Future: Three Big Airlines Would Bring Scale, Higher Fees
summary: For consumers, a merger of American Airlines and US Airways would share a lot of the characteristics of a typical airline flight: You would encounter aggravations and pleasures, some higher fees and costs, and in the end, you may land in a better place.

headline: Canada's Conservatives Split in Alberta Provincial Poll
summary: Canada's version of the Tea Party movement is hoping to stage one of the country's biggest political upsets by unseating the center-right party that has governed the oil-rich province of Alberta for decades.

headline: Cool Canada?
summary: Canadian cities set the music agenda, says a study using network theory. Also in this week's column, an East-West facial divide and why faking it sometimes means making it.

headline: Democrats for Keystone
summary: Obama is losing support for his pipeline obstructionism.

headline: Bahrainis Clash Ahead of F1 Race
summary: Tens of thousands of anti-government protesters demonstrated against the staging of the Formula One race in Bahrain this weekend.

headline: Why the Boss Is Such an Ape
summary: Matt Ridley looks at the lessons about societies of humans, chimpanzees and apes in Dario Maestripieri's "Games Primates Play."

headline: Chesapeake Valuation for Oil Services
summary: You can say this for Chesapeake Energy's plan to sell its oil-field services business: It hired the best salesman. But even Goldman Sachs could have a hard job selling this one.

headline: Billionaire Families Join Pledge on Giving
summary: The billionaire founders of PayPal and Broadcom are among a dozen wealthy families that have agreed to give the majority of their wealth to charity.

headline: A Researcher and a Robot Walk Into a Bar...
summary: The stand-up comedy act of social roboticist Heather Knight and her robot Data have inspired a viral following.

headline: Where Are the Next Clown Princes?
summary: In entertainment and politics, the specter looms of a talent-thin bench of idiots and doofuses. Joe Queenan on a missing generation to fill the shoes of Hugo Chávez and Paris Hilton.

headline: Tall Tales
summary: An artistic take on the cross sections of trees, from Bryan Nash Gill's new book "Woodcut."

headline: Coach Harmon on Woods: 'Very Robotic'
summary: Butch Harmon, Tiger Woods's coach from 1993-2004, speaks out on his protégé—and Hank Haney.

headline: FDA Alerts Doctors on Fakes
summary: The FDA warned more than 50 doctors and medical practices in the U.S. that they may have bought a fake version of the cancer drug Avastin.

headline: The Agony of Writing
summary: Anna Quindlen on the ways she keeps writing: Take a power walk. Play Sondheim. Don't talk about what you're working on and don't finish the day's last sentence.

headline: A Bridge to Eternity
summary: On a paris hilltop, a magnificent and insufficiently celebrated treasure.

headline: The Problem With Patents
summary: Holly Finn on how to fix our broken patent system.

headline: Students Stage Violent Riot in Montreal
summary: Weeks of student protests over proposed tuition hikes in Quebec turned violent after hundreds clashed with riot police in downtown Montreal.

headline: US Air Faces AMR Hurdles
summary: US Airways faces big hurdles if it pursues a merger with American Airlines, a deal that would create the world's second-largest carrier.

headline: Ideas Calendar: April 21-27
summary: On the agenda this week: a health conference at Yale, the World Shakespeare Festival kicks off and a legal historian discusses Islamic law.

headline: Five Best Books: Newspaper Owners
summary: Author Amanda Smith on books about press moguls, including William Randolph Hearst and Joseph Pulitzer—but also Evelyn Waugh's Lord Copper.

headline: The Owner Threw Knuckleballs
summary: Paul Dickson's biography of baseball impresario Bill Veeck captures the fun and frivolity brought to the sport by the man who owned, at various points, the Cleveland Indians, St. Louis Browns and Chicago White Sox (twice). But the book also shows how Veeck helped permanently change the game. Maxwell Carter reviews.

headline: Treasury Prices Retreat
summary: Treasury bonds slipped for the first time in three sessions, but the benchmark 10-year note's yield stayed below 2% on uncertainty about the euro zone's sovereign-debt crisis.

headline: A Master's Riffs on Centuries of Chinese Art
summary: "Revolutionary Ink: The Paintings of Wu Guanzhong" opens at the Asia Society Museum in New York.

headline: This Week
summary: Stocks eked out a gain this week; home sales had their worst monthly drop since August; and more investors cited the economy as a concern, a survey found.

headline: A Rare Day at Auschwitz
summary: More than 10,000 people gathered Thursday at the former Auschwitz concentration camp in Oswiecim, Poland, for a march marking Holocaust Remembrance Day.

headline: ECB Draghi: Debt-Crisis Strategy 'Falling Into Place'
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi says Europe's strategy to resolve the debt crisis "is falling into place," referring to a four-pronged approach involving structural economic reforms, fiscal belt-tightening, financial firewalls and price stability.

headline: At Auschwitz's Gate, a Reunion
summary: A survivor of the Buchenwald concentration camp and one of his liberators were among more than 10,000 people who gathered to mark Holocaust Remembrance Day with a march from Auschwitz to Birkenau.

headline: Alternative Drug Programs that Yield Results
summary: Prohibition and legalization aren't our only choices when it comes to drugs. Here is a look at one program in Hempstead, New York, that has lead to long-established markets disappearing overnight.

headline: Mating Season Flushes Out Vice-Presidential Suitors
summary: Romney kicks off the process of selecting a running mate.

headline: Drogba Is Hurt, and Chelsea Is in Trouble
summary: Didier Drogba is banged up as Chelsea heads into a critical stretch. Plus, the tireless Justin Verlander is back on the mound.

headline: Some Monopolies Are More Equal
summary: Federal Trade Commission pressure prevented the merger of two Illinois hospitals ("Hospitals Drop Plan for Merger," Corporate News, April 13) while a much broader health-care funding monopoly, a single-payer system, may be the end result of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Joplin and Tuscaloosa's Approaches to Disaster Recovery
summary: Regarding David T. Beito and Daniel J. Smith's "Tornado Recovery: How Joplin Is Beating Tuscaloosa" (Cross Country, April 14): While Joplin, Mo., appears to be outpacing Tuscaloosa, Ala., in rebuilding.

headline: A Punk's Progress
summary: In "Commando," the Ramones' guitarist, Johnny Ramone, recalls his time in the greatest punk band ever. Ken Kurson reviews.

headline: Our Stadium Project Is Properly Done
summary: The renovation of University of California-Berkeley's Memorial Stadium was always intended to be debt-financed and paid for with revenue generated by Intercollegiate Athletics, including the sale of football seats, over the life of the project ("Cal's Football-Stadium Gamble," Sports, April 18).

headline: Nobody but Me Pays My Commuting Costs
summary: Why should any citizen have to pay the bill for Defense Secretary Leon Panetta to commute between where he chooses to live and his place of work ("Panetta Says He Regrets Expense of Trips Home," U.S. News, April 17)?

headline: We Must Assure Our Skies Are Both Safe and Friendly
summary: Kip Hawley, the Transportation Security Administration's former administrator, fails to acknowledge a November 2011 congressional report documenting that the TSA has become a bloated, 65,000-person bureaucracy.

headline: Vases, Chairs and 160 Years of Fairs
summary: At the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., "Inventing the Modern World: Decorative Arts at the World's Fairs, 1851-1939" showcases nearly 200 objects drawn from every major fair in that period.

headline: Tempur-Pedic International, Riverbed Technology: Biggest Price Decliners (TPX, RVBD)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Infoblox, New Century Bancorp: Biggest Price Gainers (BLOX, NCBC)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Wells Fargo, Exxon Mobil: Money Flow Leaders (WFC, XOM)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: In Brief: Gastronomy
summary: "Ripe" is a beautifully illustrated and imaginatively organized survey of some of the best varieties of fruits and vegetables available to almost any American with access to a good supermarket.

headline: A Census of Endings
summary: "Megacatastrophes!" explores nine kinds of disaster—gamma rays, plague, supervolcano—that could end the world. Tom Shippey reviews.

headline: Trouble in Paradise
summary: "Midnight in Peking" tells the story of the haunting murder of a young Englishwoman in 1930s China. Fergus M. Bordewich reviews.

headline: Happily Home Alone
summary: Two 11-year-olds and their summer in Cape Cod; two apartment-block-dwelling children who one day discover a tiny house behind their building; and the frustrations—and eventual joy—of life with a baby sister: Meghan Cox Gurdon reviews the latest in children's literature.

headline: Women's War on Women
summary: "The Conflict" argues that the rise of attachment parenting has hurt mothers and driven families apart. Molly Guinness reviews.

headline: Fiction Chronicle: The Art of Conversation as  Aphrodisiac
summary: In Andrés Neuman's "Traveler of the Century," garrulous debate in a salon can also be seductive; Laurent Binet's "HHhH" takes the historical-fiction approach to the wartime assassination of notorious Nazi Reinhard Heydrich; April Bernard's novel "Miss Fuller" also concerns a historical figure: Margaret Fuller, historian, journalist and member of the Boston Transcendentalists. Sam Sacks reviews.

headline: Mexican Volcano Spouts Rock, Ash
summary: Mexico's Popocatépetl volcano is spouting gases and hot rock fragments and dusting towns nearby with ash.

headline: CFTC: Speculative Investors Pull Back On Pro-Dollar Bets
summary: Speculative investors slightly pared their anti-yen bets a little more than a week before the Bank of Japan's upcoming meeting, according to data released by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

headline: Congress Eyes 401(k)s Again
summary: The increasing focus on retirement savings is a reminder that tax treatment of the accounts, once considered permanent, is anything but.

headline: Cartier's '70s Show; Ferragamo Travel Totes
summary: Cartier opens the doors of its famous Fifth Avenue mansion for an exhibition celebrating the house's groovy '70s designs; Ferragamo releases a limited number of exquisitely old-fashioned totes inspired by old-fashioned train travel at their new Manhattan store.

headline: Avant-Garde Architecture in Alabama
summary: Auburn University's Rural Studio program has turned a swath of Alabama countryside into a hotbed of innovative, sustainable architecture.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In Friday's pictures, girls wait for school to start in Sierra Leone, rescue workers review a crash scene in Islamabad, a tennis player catches his breath in Monaco, and more.

headline: MetLife Reports Loss After Snafu
summary: MetLife said it swung to a loss on increased derivative losses, releasing the preliminary results nearly two weeks ahead of schedule after inadvertently posting some quarterly data on its website Wednesday.

headline: India Assures U.S on Tax Moves
summary: Seeking to tamp down a growing controversy over India's investment climate, Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee assured U.S. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner that recent Indian tax proposals that have rattled foreign investors are "not substantive but clarificatory."

headline: Photos of the Day: April 20
summary: In today's pictures, girls wait for school to start in Sierra Leone, rescue workers review a crash scene in Islamabad, a tennis player catches his breath in Monaco, and more.

headline: McDonald's Sales, Profit Rise
summary: McDonald's reported a 4.8% rise in quarterly profit as the world's largest fast-food chain continued to show resilience in the face of economic headwinds.

headline: Michaels Stores CEO Is Hospitalized
summary: Michaels Stores said CEO John Menzer has been hospitalized and is in stable condition.

headline: Kia's Hybrid Sets a Commuter Standard
summary: There are certainly fleeter and more-fun cars than the Kia Optima Hybrid, but no family sedan gathers up value, looks and efficiency quite like it, says Dan Neil.

headline: EU Body Backs Diabetes Drug U.S. Rejected
summary: Advisers to the European drug regulator recommended approval of an experimental diabetes drug that was rejected by U.S. regulators. The drug's co-developers are Bristol-Myers Squibb and AstraZeneca.

headline: Fiat Readies New Sedan for China
summary: Fiat will show its first car made with a local Chinese partner on Monday at the Beijing International Automotive Exhibition, a belated attempt to catch rivals that are better established in China.

headline: Value, Looks, Efficiency
summary: There are certainly fleeter and more-fun cars than the Optima Hybrid, but no family sedan gathers up value, looks and efficiency quite like it, says Dan Neil.
